paragraph: The Tale of Two Bad Mice Beatrix Potter
tokens: bad

paragraph: BOOK 1.
ONCE upon a time there was a very beautiful doll's-house; it was red brick with white windows, and it had real muslin curtains and a front door and a chimney.
tokens: time be beautiful doll house red brick white window have real muslin curtain front door chimney

paragraph: IT belonged to two Dolls called Lucinda and Jane; at least it belonged to Lucinda, but she never ordered meals.
tokens: belong doll call least belong order meal

paragraph: Jane was the Cook; but she never did any cooking, because the dinner had been bought ready-made, in a box full of shavings.
tokens: cook do cooking dinner buy ready make box full shaving

paragraph: THERE were two red lobsters and a ham, a fish, a pudding, and some pears and oranges.
tokens: red lobster ham fish pudding pear orange

paragraph: They would not come off the plates, but they were extremely beautiful.
tokens: come plate beautiful

paragraph: ONE morning Lucinda and Jane had gone out for a drive in the doll's perambulator. There was no one in the nursery, and it was very quiet. Presently there was a little scuffling, scratching noise in a corner near the fire-place, where there was a hole under the skirting-board.
tokens: morning go drive doll perambulator be nursery quiet be little scuffling scratch noise corner fire place be hole skirting board

paragraph: Tom Thumb put out his head for a moment, and then popped it in again.
tokens: put head moment pop

paragraph: Tom Thumb was a mouse.
tokens: mouse

paragraph: A MINUTE afterwards, Hunca Munca, his wife, put her head out, too; and when she saw that there was no one in the nursery, she ventured out on the oilcloth under the coal-box.
tokens: minute wife put head see be nursery venture oilcloth coal box

paragraph: THE doll's-house stood at the other side of the fire-place. Tom Thumb and Hunca Munca went cautiously across the hearthrug. They pushed the front door--it was not fast.
tokens: doll house stand other side fire place go hearthrug push front door fast

paragraph: TOM THUMB and Hunca Munca went upstairs and peeped into the dining-room. Then they squeaked with joy!
tokens: go peep dining room squeak joy

paragraph: Such a lovely dinner was laid out upon the table! There were tin spoons, and lead knives and forks, and two dolly-chairs--all _so_ convenient!
tokens: lovely dinner lay table be tin spoon lead knife fork dolly chair _so_ convenient

paragraph: TOM THUMB set to work at once to carve the ham. It was a beautiful shiny yellow, streaked with red.
tokens: thumb set work carve ham beautiful shiny yellow streak red

paragraph: The knife crumpled up and hurt him; he put his finger in his mouth.
tokens: knife crumple hurt put finger mouth

paragraph: "It is not boiled enough; it is hard. You have a try, Hunca Munca."
tokens: boil hard have try

paragraph: HUNCA MUNCA stood up in her chair, and chopped at the ham with another lead knife.
tokens: stand chair choppe ham lead knife

paragraph: "It's as hard as the hams at the cheesemonger's," said Hunca Munca.
tokens: hard ham cheesemonger say

paragraph: THE ham broke off the plate with a jerk, and rolled under the table.
tokens: ham break plate jerk roll table

paragraph: "Let it alone," said Tom Thumb; "give me some fish, Hunca Munca!"
tokens: let say give fish

paragraph: HUNCA MUNCA tried every tin spoon in turn; the fish was glued to the dish.
tokens: try tin spoon turn fish glue dish

paragraph: Then Tom Thumb lost his temper. He put the ham in the middle of the floor, and hit it with the tongs and with the shovel--bang, bang, smash, smash!
tokens: lose temper put ham middle floor hit tong shovel bang bang smash smash

paragraph: The ham flew all into pieces, for underneath the shiny paint it was made of nothing but plaster!
tokens: ham fly piece shiny paint make plaster

paragraph: THEN there was no end to the rage and disappointment of Tom Thumb and Hunca Munca. They broke up the pudding, the lobsters, the pears and the oranges.
tokens: be end rage disappointment break pudding lobster pear orange

paragraph: As the fish would not come off the plate, they put it into the red-hot crinkly paper fire in the kitchen; but it would not burn either.
tokens: fish come plate put red hot crinkly paper fire kitchen burn

paragraph: TOM THUMB went up the kitchen chimney and looked out at the top--there was no soot.
tokens: go kitchen chimney look top be soot

paragraph: WHILE Tom Thumb was up the chimney, Hunca Munca had another disappointment. She found some tiny canisters upon the dresser, labelled--Rice--Coffee--Sago--but when she turned them upside down, there was nothing inside except red and blue beads.
tokens: chimney have disappointment find tiny canister dresser label turn be red blue bead

paragraph: THEN those mice set to work to do all the mischief they could--especially Tom Thumb! He took Jane's clothes out of the chest of drawers in her bedroom, and he threw them out of the top floor window.
tokens: mouse set work do mischief take clothes chest drawer bedroom throw top floor window

paragraph: But Hunca Munca had a frugal mind. After pulling half the feathers out of Lucinda's bolster, she remembered that she herself was in want of a feather bed.
tokens: have frugal mind pull feather bolster remember want feather bed

paragraph: WITH Tom Thumb's assistance she carried the bolster downstairs, and across the hearth-rug. It was difficult to squeeze the bolster into the mouse-hole; but they managed it somehow.
tokens: assistance carry bolster hearth rug difficult squeeze bolster mouse hole manage

paragraph: THEN Hunca Munca went back and fetched a chair, a book-case, a bird-cage, and several small odds and ends. The book-case and the bird-cage refused to go into the mouse-hole.
tokens: go fetched chair book case bird cage several small odd end book case bird cage refuse go mouse hole

paragraph: HUNCA MUNCA left them behind the coal-box, and went to fetch a cradle.
tokens: leave coal box go fetch cradle

paragraph: HUNCA MUNCA was just returning with another chair, when suddenly there was a noise of talking outside upon the landing. The mice rushed back to their hole, and the dolls came into the nursery.
tokens: return chair be noise talk landing mouse rush hole doll come nursery

paragraph: WHAT a sight met the eyes of Jane and Lucinda!
tokens: sight meet eye

paragraph: Lucinda sat upon the upset kitchen stove and stared; and Jane leant against the kitchen dresser and smiled--but neither of them made any remark.
tokens: sit upset kitchen stove stare lean kitchen dresser smile make remark

paragraph: THE book-case and the bird-cage were rescued from under the coal-box--but Hunca Munca has got the cradle, and some of Lucinda's clothes.
tokens: book case bird cage rescue coal box get cradle clothes

paragraph: SHE also has some useful pots and pans, and several other things.
tokens: have useful pot pan several other thing

paragraph: THE little girl that the doll's-house belonged to, said,--"I will get a doll dressed like a policeman!"
tokens: little girl doll house belong say get doll dress policeman

paragraph: BUT the nurse said,--"I will set a mouse-trap!"
tokens: nurse say set mouse trap

paragraph: SO that is the story of the two Bad Mice,--but they were not so very very naughty after all, because Tom Thumb paid for everything he broke.
tokens: story bad naughty pay break

paragraph: He found a crooked sixpence under the hearthrug; and upon Christmas Eve, he and Hunca Munca stuffed it into one of the stockings of Lucinda and Jane.
tokens: find crooked sixpence hearthrug stuff stocking

paragraph: AND very early every morning--before anybody is awake--Hunca Munca comes with her dust-pan and her broom to sweep the Dollies' house!
tokens: morning awake come dust pan broom sweep house

paragraph: THE END.
tokens: end
